reviewerName: Ash "Im a Michigan native who loves reading ...
reviewText: Academy city is a technologically advanced city comprised mostly of schools and dormitories for the students that attend them. As a result 80% of the people living in the city are students there to study and hone their abilities known as esper powers. After Toma a student in Academy city meets Index a young nun on the run from pursuers he quickly becomes embroiled in the conflicts of sorcerers.The animation is gorgeous, the characters are compelling, the story is intriguing although I thought the spinoff series ("a certain scientific railgun") had a better story and the English dub is excellent making this series a must own for any anime fan, but the spinoff series "a certain scientific railgun" is better!
summary: Very good, but spinoff series is better!

reviewText: Anime, when playing to it's strength, can be imaginative, visually interesting, with few of the limits of live action TV.  Far too often, anime falls short, especially in the imaginative area.  Thankfully, this series gets it right, building an interesting, visually appealing world filled with fascinating characters.Based on the light novel series written by Kazuma Kamachi which have sold over 10 million copies(series is not licensed in English to my novel, but is available online and well worth finding and reading), Index starts out simply, with a chance meeting with between Toma Kamijo(alternately spelled Touma Kamijou, which is probably more accurate) and Index Librorum Prohibitorum.  While the first meeting does not go great, Toma is still drawn into fighting for her when he later finds her injured and threatened.  Toma is a basically good person, who will fight to defend those who need it, and with his "Imagine Breaker" power, the power to negate any supernatural, ESP or magical ability with his right hand making him somewhat formidable when he does need to fight.The characters are one of the better aspects of the series.  Toma is a basically good person who will, before long, do anything to protect Index and keep her smiling.  Index is hilarious, kind hearted and powerful in her own way.  Mikota Misaka is brash, loud and harboring a tragic secret.  Stiyl Magnus is, well, to avoid spoilers, let us just say he is fascinating.  Aisa Himegami is sad and kind.  The character design and art are uniformly strong and interesting.  Voice acting in both Japanese and English range from acceptable to well done.  Special note should be made of Monica Rial as the voice of Index.  I was appalled to learn that she had this important role.  While I love some of her work, she has always struck me as some one best suited for a small side role, doing to voice of the token loli.  I simply did not think she would have the ability to pull off a major role like Index.  I am happy to say that I was very wrong, and her voicing of Index was a major pleasure to listen to.Also of note for this series is the look of the world.  The world where the series takes place, much like modern day Earth, but with magic and ESP both working.  The scenery of Academy City is surprisingly interesting, with windmills all over, cleaning robots and small blimps popping up everywhere.  It is very creative and visually appealing.But of course, the most important part of any story is the plot.  This set contains two storylines plus part of a third, matching up with the first 2 and a half(the third storyline based on the third novel is cut in half, the second half being on the second DVD set) light novels.  In the interest of avoiding spoilers I am not going to describe the plots themselves.  What is important is that the light novel series has sold so well because of their fascinating plots.  While the anime makes some minor changes and is forced to cut out some aspects, they manage to make good decisions on what to keep and what to cut, and do a great job of telling the stories from the LNs.  The stories have great twists, many surprises, moments of epic adventure(well animated, the fighting sequences are very well done, possibly stronger even than the LNs), many laughs, a few tears, and some great mood whiplash type moments.I knew going in that I was going to like this series, but I had no idea just how much I would like it.  While not perfect, it is a very strong series with no major flaws, and it is easy to overlook the small ones.  There are very few anime out there more worthy of your money than this one.  I am anxiously scraping together the cash to get volume two, and waiting even more anxiously for the spinoff series A Certain Scientific Railgun to get released.One last note:  Dear Funimation:  voice actor commentary for a couple episodes and textless songs are a very weak set of extras, to the point where it is not even worth calling them extras.  What makes it worse is when one of the voice actors doing the commentary only appears in 2 episodes, briefly, and does not even recognize the title character in the opening credits.  Extras is an area where your company is very weak, please fix that.
summary: A Good Example of What Anime Can Be When Done Right

reviewText: This series is pretty good, some great comedy here. I like the idea of espers (supernatural power wielders) and magic wielding  sorcerers, who are on opposite sides of the spectrum in this series. I personally like Index, the sister with hundreds of grimoires in her head, despite reading reviews that she is annoying. I think she is cute and funny and you get emotionally attached to her. One complaint I have of this series is that the story kind of veers away from Index right as you start to get really curious about her past and where she is going :( Other than that, breathtaking art and not a bad english dub either (although some are hardcore japanese viewers and hate all english dubs).

reviewText: Judging this Index by its cover would definitely be a mistake.  This is by far the most intelligent of the Harem genre.  For newcomers to anime, Harem refers to the shows that focus on a sexually naive male character sandwiched between every cliché' female archetype imaginable.  And yes, there is an entire genre to support platforms that let youths live vicariously through a boy who's completely smothered in breasts, panties and pixie dust.  Most of them are shamefully dim, but with all genres, there is a good version of everything.  A Certain Magical Index is that gem that should not be thrown away onto that sticky DVD pile of teen angst.The main character lives in a futuristic city where science has created a culture of Espers (people who have developed special powers).  Our hero can't use any because his right hand mysteriously cancels out these abilities.  It seems like a curse but is obviously the best defense in a world like this.  Index (the chick) uses magic, ends up on his doorstep hiding from sorcerers and is the tortured keeper of the entire encyclopedia of dark arts.It's science versus magic, the never ending knowledge of one, and the right hand to cancel them both.  This series is paced to perfection.  Nothing drags unnecessarily.  The fights are all strategic, and the main character (for once) is intelligent enough to win them.  The mystery surrounding Index and her church is not paper thin and unfolds timely and with intrigue.  The origin of the Espers and their science driven powers are a whole other enigma in itself.Add fully fleshed out characters, thought provoking, beautifully animated battles, and constant mind wiping worthy of a Nolan script and you've got a recipe for a stellar show.  The Harem aspect of the series drifts in and out delivering some needed comedy, but sits patiently in the back seat letting the intelligence of the show drive.This whole series has another volume and a spinoff (A Certain Scientific Rail gun).  A 5 star rating is pending.  If it doesn't keep up, then the praise stops here with 4 stars.  I've seen way too many anime shows that start off with an exceptional premise that soon spirals out of control and loses itself reaching for epic, unleashing dues ex machina monsters that kick the sense out of it until it's left panting and hemorrhaging on the ground wondering which way is up.I'm on to part 2 and recommend fans do the same.  This is definitely an anime worth watching and finally a Harem worthy of praise.
summary: A Harem show that doesn't insult every brain cell!?

reviewText: If you like any genre of anime you'll like AMCI - this series is beyond great!  The mix of characters and their individual profiles, comedy, drama - everything is dead on the money.  As I watched I didn't even find what I'd call a "lull" in my interest which is common enough even in series I've truly loved.  I don't see how anyone would be disappointed with this one - best I've seen in 6 months.  Had to stop several times while I was laughing just so I didn't miss the remainder of or the next scene! :-)

reviewText: Review for part 1Kamijo lives in Academy City, where people use science to develop supernatural abilities. Kamijo doesn't have any supernatural abilities, other than being able to cancel out supernatural powers. One day he meets a nun called Index. Index holds 103,000 volumes of magic knowledge in her memory. There are a couple of sorcerers form her sect that are after her. Kamijo decides that he's going to protect her. He learns that Index only remembers the past year of her life, and upon fighting the sorcerers, he also learns that her brain can only hold one year of memories. Every year her memories are reset and all that remains is the knowledge of the 103,000 volumes. Kamijo finds a way to save her and prevent her from having to erase her memories. Unfortunately, that's just the beginning of the journey.This series is a lot of fun. It has a lot of drama, action, and comedy. The animation, voice acting, and soundtrack are all very good. The characters are interesting and very memorable. This series reminds me of Shakugan No Shana, D. Gray-Man, Fate Stay/Night, and Air. If you liked any of those, you'll probably enjoy this series too. It's very well rounded, there is are several different themes in this series: Sci-Fi, Drama, and harem are all major themes. I think that just about any anime fan can enjoy A Certain Magical Index. I loved part 1, and I can't wait for part 2. It's probably best to buy this from Amazon, Rightstuf wants almost double the price that Amazon is asking.Review For Part 2The above is the review for part 1. For some reason Amazon put my review for part one under the part 2 section as well. I'll review part 2 below.Part 2 begins where part 1 left off. Kamijo has decided to help Misaka save her clone sisters. He takes on the Accelerator in a great battle. There are a few other story arcs in part 2. Kamijo and his friends get stuck in an elaborate fantasy world, he plays Misaka's boyfriend for a day, and a rogue member of the English Church tries to start a war between Espers and Magicians. Not a whole lot of story advancement is made in part 2. Especially the relationship between Index and Kamijo. Index is neglected big time in part 2 I think. Part 2 is still pretty good. If you enjoyed part 1, you'll like part 2. Just don't expect as much. The quality is still awesome. Part 1 is just way more dramatic and intense. While I give part 1 5 stars, I think that part 2 only deserves 4. It's still a great anime, and I believe there is also a season 2. I don't think it's been dubbed and released in English yet. Either way, A Certain Magical Index is amazing and definitely a must see for all anime fans.

reviewText: If you've seen other anime series like Shakugan No Shanna,Fate/Stay Night or Full Metal Alchemist then the story on this series shouldn't surprise you to much. The series two primary characters are Tōma Kamijō a young male high school student who possesses a right hand that negates all magical/psychic/divine powers but also humorously in the anime also negates good luck for the most part though not all of it, and then we have a young female dressed as a holy nun named Index Librorum Prohibitorum who possess inside her mind a total of 103,000 magical texts and is usually guarded closely by the holy church which have their own somewhat dark agenda in the history of Index.  Like the previous mentioned series this one will have the usual but entertaining mix of action/humor/drama/romance/sorrow but like with half the series that do this the characters and storyline of the series make it a very entertaining and enjoyable series.  The animation is clear and sharp and somewhat reminiscent of the style of Shakugan No Shanna also as expected from Funimation the English dubbed cast did a terrific job with their character roles and the Japanese subbed as always did a superb job too.  The series set is in the more reasonable price range due mostly because this is not a blu-ray/dvd combo set but just the standard regular dvd release, but the set is sure to come out on blu-ray with enough fan support.So if you like mystical psychic battles with a mix of hilarity and romance with a cast of endearing characters and decent story here's one to add to  your anime library......
summary: Overall Enjoyable If Somewhat Generic Series

reviewText: it is a little disappointing that this show is a bit underrated in the US considering it is by far one of the best series out there. to make thing short and cliched, boy had bad luck with anti-super nature power in his hand who live in a city where everyone have superpower due to science, meet girl who getting chase by people who have supernatural power by magic.  cliched and predictable right? yes, but that only the surface of this show. the protagonist is extremely likable in a way that he is the underdog of the show, consider his power is worthless in everyday life, but put in a situation where he must rise to the challenge and become a hero.  he fight using wit, skill and word instead of ur average over the top power up. in fact, throu out the show, he didnt receive a single power up, he just enter the tray because he knew that if he didnt help them, nobody will and they are doom, that my friend is what it truthfully mean to be brave, considering he literally have to fight, and fire deity, a reality warper, an super"hero", a angel and a doppelganger, in this first part.The second part have is my personal favorite since the special thing about this show is that there are never just one protagonist, everyone have their reason, everyone have their motive, the person u fight doesnt necessary always be a bad guy. for example, one of the antagonist of one chapter, become the second hero of the series, or more accurately,an anti hero who seek redemption for his sin.the novel will eventually introduce a lot more character, and explain how each of their fate intertwine.  please support this series so that it get the reputation it desert since anime like this is what truthfully deserting of it.  so far, the anime faithfully follow the novel, so hopefully it will follow that path and not creating a non-canon endingthis series have a lot  of depth in it, and the anime does a good job of capture most of the charm of the light novel, but not all of it. anyway, i definably recommend this for anime fan out there, especially for ppl like me who enjoy watching the underdog win instead of typical shonen power up heroes.
summary: science magic, and a who lot of harem
